review_blob: 22 oz. bottle shared by Pubolyons. Amber/orange pour with a decent size off white head. Modest lace on my taster glass. Earthy, somewhat spicy aroma. Fair amount of malt. Flavor tries to be malty and it mostly succeeds, but theres an oddness about it. Mild fruit. Medium bodied. Thanks Jeff.

12 oz. can, courtesy of AirForceHops. Pours a slightly hazed pale straw with a one finger white head. Cereal grains and bread on the nose. Grain based flavor that leans lightly sweet. Light bodied and finishes dry.
beer_name: White Birch Small Batch Ale Pilsner

review_blob: 2 oz bottle, courtesy of jcwattsrugger. Poured dark brown, almost black with a thin mocha ring. Wonderful brownie batter aroma, just smells delicious. Some coffee in the sweet flavor. Think coffee with cream while eating a hot from the oven brownie. Medium to full body. Very nice!
beer_name: Tampa Bay Iron Rat Imperial Stout - Cocoa Nibs

review_blob: 12 oz can? Courtesy of jcwattsrugger, Pale yellow with a thin white head. Bready aroma. Flavor follows. Thin bodied.
22 oz bottle. Poured dark brown with a beige head. Faint oatmeal aroma. Oatmeal flavor with light vanilla. Medium bodied and dry.

22 oz bottle, courtesy of jcwattsrugger. Sweet rum soaked candy aroma. Slight vegetal. Very sweet flavor. More candy. Not much pumpkin. Whispers. Medium bodied. Pretty good, Would be better if there was more pumpkin.

From a growler courtesy of jcwattsrugger.
Pours a straw color with a thin white head. Mild hop aroma, grassy. Malty undertone. Light sweetness. Fresh. Medium bodied. Good.

Growler from Pubolyons, Dark brown pour with a thin beige head. Milk chocolate nose. Hint of lactose, Milk chocolate semi sweetness. If the orange peel is in there , its faint. Medium bodied. Nice! Im impressed.

22 oz. bottle, dated 03/12/16. Pours a deep gold, slightly hazed, with a fingers worth of bubbly white head. Light Belgian yeast and white pepper on the aroma. Secondary malt scents. Faintly sweet with a light malt, almost non existent hops and a flavor that must be the rosehips. Has a slight Belgian funk. To the light side and dry. Nice.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear glowing orange gold with a fingers worth of white head. Simply beautiful to behold. Like a sunset after a perfect day. Pop the cap and pour and you are assaulted with every hop scent imaginable. Just smells fresh and inviting. Primarily tropical fruits, citrus and pine, which pretty much covers the spectrum. The same can be said for the flavor. Its bracingly bitter at times, yet theres an undertone of sweetness. Full bodied with a lingering bitter finish as by now, your tongue is saturated with hop oils. Very good!

16 oz. can from The Beer Store. Pours light orange a 1/4" dense white head. Nice lace. Dank, musty aroma. Cantaloupe and other ripe melons. Wet basement. hints of sweetness in the flavor with tropical fruit notes. Good amount of malt. Full bodied with a lasting bitterness.

Draft at Marthas. Served in a pint glass. Pours a hazed yellow gold with a one finger white head that hangs around a while. Light pine and wild grass on the aroma. Light pink grapefruit and citrus on the flavor. Not sweet, but not sharp either. Medium bodied and finished with a lingering bitterness.

4 oz. taster at the source on opening day and bought a 32 oz. growler. Poured a darker hued red/amber with a thin ring of a head. Sweet toffee and caramel malt on the nose. Sweet flavor with a bit of earth. Kind of like their pale ale, ramped up a few notches. The best beer of the three I had on opening day.

4 oz. taster at the source. Poured amber with a small white head. Aroma was sour, spoiled vegetation. Quite acidic. Tasted pretty awful. Like gasoline. I dont know if they had infected lines or what, but this was not good. After the decent pale ale, this was a major let down.

4 oz. taster at the source on opening day. Amber/gold with a white head. Caramel malt and earth on the nose. Light pine. More forest floor than actual pine resin. Lightly sweet flavor. More malt than hops. Easy on the tongue. Smooth and easy to drink.

22 oz. bottle from the source on release day. Poured into a snifter at cellar temperature. Pours black as midnight with a small off white head that quickly recedes to a ring. Spotty lace. Aroma is predominately chocolate and cocoa nibs. Light bourbon notes. As you would expect from the deScription, the taste is sweet chocolate with bourbon notes and a hint of oak tannin. I like that the bourbon is soft and in the background. Mouth feel is silky smooth and soft. Full bodied. A nice beer, indeed!.

Multiple samples @ Brew Woo 16. They werent collecting tickets and I really liked it,so went back a few times. Poured a light orange with a minimal white head, just a ring really. Light caramel sweetness on the nose with a soft whisper of booze. Sweet flavors of caramel and candied fruits. Enough booze to be noticed, but not overwhelming. Full bodied with a lingering sweetness.

beer_brewer_name: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
review_blob: Sampled @ Brew Woo 16. Poured pale yellow with a fluffy white head. Mild citrus aroma with secondary bread grains. Watered down hop flavor profile. Light in body and flavor. Not much going on. Ok as a session style brew I guess.

Sampled @ Brew Woo 16. Poured reddish/amber with a minimal white head that quickly retreated to a ring. Aroma and flavor of sweat soaked leather work gloves or an old baseball mitt. I mean that in a good way, sort of. Sour and wild enough to be interesting, but not so much as to be off putting. Everybody in my party hated it, so I intended up with their samples as well as my own.

Sampled at Brew Woo 16. Poured black with a mocha colored head. Modest lace. Aroma is light chocolate, coffee with cream and a touch of smoke. Semi sweet flavor of cocoa, dampened down with mild molasses and earthy hops. Full in the mouth. Nice!

4 oz. sample at Brew Woo 16. Pours black as night with a brown foamy head. Heavy roasted malt aroma with a hint of expresso. Rich chocolate malt and coffee on the taste with some earthy hops detected when you let it linger in your mouth. Full bodied and intense. Nice!

12 oz. can from The Beer Store, into a snifter. Pours dark brown with a one finger mocha colored head. Decent lace. Chocolate aroma. Sweet chocolate flavor. Maybe a tiny bit of brine on the backend of the swallow. Could have been a little more. Medium bodied. Nice stout, just dont know where the oysters went.

Bottle from a 4 pack given to me by my daughter, who lives in Mass. Pours a hazed amber/orange with a fingers worth of beige head. Modest lace. Slightly sweet tropical fruit aroma with floral undertones. More mild sweetness in the flavor with a certain earthiness to it. Quite malty for an IPA, not a bad thing in my opinion. Body to the full side. I really enjoyed it.

12 oz. bottle from a 12 pack purchased at a local grocery store. Pours a slightly cloudy gold with a 1/2" off white head. Modest lace. Sharp hop aroma, almost astringent. Intense hop flavor profile as well. I thought with the name and the commercial deScription, the flavor would be slightly softer. Not much balance. Still good, just not what I expected. Bitter on the palate with a bitter lasting finish.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Beer Camp Tropical IPA

review_blob: 750ml bottle, courtesy of an Easter guest. Poured a slightly murky chestnut brown with a one finger creamy khaki head. Some lace. Dark fruits and sweetness on the aroma. Hint of maple. Sweet flavors of brown sugar, candied cherries, a hint of molasses and a light spice. Medium bodied with a fairly high level of carbonation. Finishes a bit dry. Tasty!
beer_name: Ommegang Game of Thrones #4 - Valar Morghulis

review_blob: 12 oz. can from The Beer Store. Pretty red brown pour with a 3/8" off white head. Modest lace. Fairly strong coffee aroma and taste. Hints at sweetness with a background of chocolate. Makes one think of an iced coffee with an expresso shot in it. Medium body. Bitter coffee aftertaste.
beer_name: Funky Bow Midnight Special Coffee Porter

review_blob: 22 oz. bottle. Bottled 10/01/15. Pours a slightly hazed red/amber with a one fingers worth of dense, creamy off white head. Brown sugar and toffee on the aroma with secondary dark fruits. Light coffee. More dark fruit on the flavor, prunes, raisins, dates and as the beer warms in my hand, some coffee bean. A bit on the boozy side. Full bodied and gut warming. Nice.

Pint at Cask & Vine a few days after the big anniversary party. I got the 2nd to last pint in the cask. What a treat. Served in a pint glass. Pours a dark brown with some reddish highlights. Two finger bubbly beige head quickly settled down so I could get to business. Caramel malt and oak tannin on the aroma. Big sweet flavor with chocolate notes, balanced by earthy hops, all with a nice woody background. Fullish body. Very nice!

4 oz. sample at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with a 1/4" white head. Bright, resinous aroma. Semi sweet with less sharpness than the aroma. Notes of juicy tropical fruits tone down the pine resin. Medium bodied with a clean, dry finish.

On tap at the source. Poured a deep chestnut brown with a thin beige cap that quickly retreated. Light coffee and malt aroma. Flavor begins as just another porter and as it warms, stronger coffee notes and chocolate malts begin to appear. Also, fairly hoppy for a porter. Medium bodied with no discernable finish. Good.

on tap at the source and a growler brought home. Pours dark, almost black with a thin tan head. Light peanut butter and chocolate aroma. Flavor follows. Fullish body, but doesnt seem heavy Pretty darn good. I noticed the abv was listed at 10% at the brewery, not the 7.2% listed here. I could feel it, so I believe it.

12oz. bottle. Poured into a snifter. Poured dark chocolate brown with a thick, creamy tan head that receded slowly, leaving nice lace. Coffee, chocolate, dark roasted malt and earth on the aroma. Sweetish flavor. Light coffee notes with chocolate with some earthy hop notes. I found the flavor more chocolate than coffee. Nice full body and smooth.

12 oz. bottle. Poured a dark mahogany with a good sized beige cap. Rye and dark fruit on the aroma. Some brown sugar too. Light sweetness with notes of brown sugar and caramel and dark pitted fruit. Sweetness is kept in check by the spiciness from the rye. Medium to full body. Excellent brew.

On tap @ Kilkennys. Pours light mahogany brown with a one finger beige head. Minor lace. Pretty dark for an IPA. Caramel and brown bread on the aroma with secondary pine. Earthy. Semi sweet. Medium bodied. Enjoyable, but I question its status as an IPA.

12 oz. bottle dated 12/28/15. Pours a darkest brown, almost black, with a one finger mocha colored head. Looks just like you think it should. Sweet chocolate aroma with secondary molasses and dark fruit. Flavor is sweet, with that chocolate aroma, how could it not be. Earthy. Medium bodied and smooth. A hint of bitterness on the swallow. Nice.

4 oz. taster at the source. Poured yellow with a small white head. Sinus clearing jalepeno aroma with a bit of citrus. Jalopeno overwhelms the palate so not much else shows through. Still, pretty good, if you like this sort of thing. Medium bodied with a hot, spicy finish. Pretty good, but make it the last taster you have.

4 oz. taster at the source. Pours gold with a slight haze and a 1/4" white head. Sharp pine resin aroma. Hop forward flavor with more pine resin. Little bit of citrus. Medium to full body. Bitter finish.
4 oz. taster at the source. Pours dark brown with a thin tannish head. Light chocolate and oatmeal on the aroma. Mildly sweet. Hints of oatmeal cookie and coffee. Medium bodied. Pretty good.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a straw color with just a hint of pink. Light, bubbly white head. About a half fingers worth. Light orange and grain on the nose. Light sweetness on the flavor. Hints at oranges and spice. Thin, light body. Just ok.

On tap at the source. Served in a snifter. Pours black with a dense, long lasting tan head. Good lace too. Aroma is roasted malt and cocoa. Light sweetness with a really nice full, creamy mouth feel. Just a hint of brine on the swallow. Not much at all really. Very nice!

22 oz. bottle. Poured into a snifter. Pours dark brown/black with ruby edges and a thin beige head. Minor legs. Light coffee and cocoa nibs on the aroma. Some nuts. Sweet, yet bitter flavor. Dark chocolate and coffee grounds. Light wood and booze. Medium bodied. Could have been a bit fuller. Very Nice!

15 oz. can. Pours black with a 2 finger dense, creamy beige head. Watching a nitro pour is kind of fun. Long lasting head with gobs of lace. Strong coffee aroma. Lots of coffee on the taste. Semi sweet. Super smooth palate with a full body. Nice!

15 oz. can, poured into a shaker pint glass. Pours a light gold with a 2 finger dense, creamy head that sticks around forever. Glass is completely coated with lace. All the above is due to the nitrogen of course, but its kind of cool. Some mild tropical fruit aromas along with some muted pine resin. Tropical flavors with a sharpness on the swallow. Full, creamy mouth feel. Some bitterness on the finish.

22 oz. bottle purchased at the brewery tasting room. Pours a gorgeous clear, glowing red/amber with a thin off white cap, which recedes to a thin ring. Light apple aroma with a hint of pear. Flavor is cooked apples, pear on a solid malt base. Hints of the oak mentioned on the bottle. moderate to full bodied. Pretty good.

650ml bottle from The Beer Store. Pours dark brown with a bubbly beige head. Aroma is light campfire smoke and ash, as well as dark malts. Flavor picks up some light coffee and some caramel, as well as some earthy hops. Body was a bit thinner than I would have liked. Finished dry. Ok, but not impressive.

Sampled @ Julios Liquors Port & Stout Fest. Poured black with a deep brown head. Minor lace. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, oak and vanilla. Sweet, yet, restrained flavor. Tiny bit of pine resin in the flavor. That and the bourbon notes tone down the sweetness. Full bodied and smooth. Very nice!
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Woodford Reserve Barrel

review_blob: Sampled @ Julios Liquors Port & Stout Fest. Poured black with a mocha head. Nose is chocolate, vanilla, caramel with a hint of coffee. Sweet and thick on the tongue.

Sampled @ Port & Stout Fest @ Julios. Poured black with a mocha colored head. Nose is chocolate, vanilla, sugar and doughnut glaze. You get a sugar rush just smelling it. Flavor is quite sweet, as you might imagine. Full bodied and oily on the tongue. A bit of alcohol burn.

Sampled @ Julios Liquors Port & Stout Fest. Poured reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is malt, earth and cinnamon. Flavor would be sweet and nice except for overwhelming cinnamon. To strong. Cinnamon aftertaste.
beer_name: Smuttynose Julios Barrel Aged Really Old Brown Dog W/ Cinnamon and Vanilla

review_blob: On tap at The Horseshoe Pub in Hudson Ma. Served in a pint glass. Poured darkest brown with a one finger white head. Recedes to a thin ring with no legs. Nose is dark roast, light chocolate and light pine resin. Hops are stronger in the flavor, pine resin and earth. Backbone of roasted malt and caramel. Bitter finish.
